(Draught) Pourshazy golden. Big fluffy head. Butterscotch and banana aroma with some soft tones of spices and lemon/citrus. Soft fudge and banana flavour with some light lemon/citrus overtones. Some dry saltyness in the finish, Light wheaty body.
50 cl bottle in Longyearbyen (!) A very standard hefe, pours cloudy and has all the elements it should have, but everything is designed to make it mainstream so it doesn’t offend anyone.
Not too bad.  Pours hazy yellow with a nice white head.  Lacing was pretty decent.  Medium bodied with some citrus flavors.

Pours a hazy straw gold, topped by better than an inch of frothy white foam. Good head retention, so-so lacing. Mild malt in the aroma.

Lightly sweet wheat flavor with a hint of honey.Hops for balance, no hop aroma, no hop flavor. A little yeast in the finish, but not enough throughout. Then a touch of honeyed citrus. Medium body, a little undercarbonated.

Ótima cerveja de trigo alemã - alta fermentação (ale), clara, coloração turva, um alaranjado claro, cheiro adocicado, leve e refrescante, bebe-se até o fim mesmo não estando com vontade. Lembra uma pilsen porém mais encorpada e mais forte, tendo um amargor maior porém sem grandes predominâncias, pouca quantidade de gás, espuma constante e intensa. Possui copo próprio, alongado (500 ml, com marcação). Valor médio de mercado alto porém abaixo do valor médio da importadas.////. Ale beer, yellow, sweet aroma, light bitter, Creamy head. A very good beer.

Cloudy, orange-ish hue, big head. Lots of wheat and a touch of citrus. Medium body, smooth finish. I was drinking it in a pub last night and it is perfect for that. Easy to drink, but tasty enough to keep you intrested. I’ll be back on this one.

Bottled. A cloudy blonde/orange beer, with a big head. The aroma is wheaty and fruity. The flavour is sweet, with a touch of bitterness at the end. The body is light. Not much interesting, I prefer the darker version.

Had it on tap at a German restaurant.  It’s not quite as thick as other hefeweizens I’ve had, but that’s fine.  This particular evening I wasn’t in the mood for a really meaty beer anyway.  Very smooth, inoffensive, and good taste.  The taste is slightly more citrus-y than the average hefe, which is refreshing.  The hops are nicely balanced, and stay in the background of the taste.  It went very well with my bratwurst, spaetzle and sauerkraut, whereas a heavier beer may have overwhelmed the flavors.  Even my wife, who does not like beer, liked this beer.  Overall, it’s a good, smooth, balanced beer that has its place and time.  I’ll come back for more.

Nice 50 cl bottle. I think it was the first German Hefe-Weizen I ever had, so I can’t judge it very good. It was quite nice, but I like Belgian Whites better, they’re more special and different from pilseners.

Not a start performer on the hefe list, but certainly one that warrants recognition.  Exceptional head and lacing with a very clear filtered appearance.  Extremely drinkable with a very smooth and satisfying palate.  There is not a whole lot of complexity with this beer, just good tasting smooth finish refreshing enjoyment.

,5 bottle. pours a bit thin, small head.  not much hefe really, more of a thin coating at the bottom of the bottle =( .  the little pieces of yeast look like lingering streamers instead of mixing in.  Has a very fresh spicy lemon aroma.  Nothing really special about the taste, more refreshing than bodied.  more citrus flavor than the usual spicy banana flavor.  It is rather heavily carbonated for my taste.  Bit of a bitter bite too.  Not bad by any means if you’re looking for something to gupl down at the beer garden.  Not really one for enjoying at home though.

I tried it off tap here in New Zealand and it is unusual to see wheat beer on tap at all. Even more unusual to see something imported (this is a country where having Stella and Heineken on tap is weird remember). Gave this beer a shot and it has to be said it is fairly inoffensive. A good quaffing beer but not the most spectacular wheat beer I have ever tasted. Yes I would go back for seconds.
Yellow, tall white head. Medium complex aroma with yeast, wheat and notes of bananas. More yeast and wheat in the flavour, bananas, and a touch of lemon too. Very nice.
Bottle.  Translucent golden yellow coloring.  Bountiful 4" head.  Wheaty, yeasty, hints of banana in aroma.  Similar in flavor with stronger emergence of lime/lemon.  Quality hefe.
Draft/Bottle.  Your everyday weissbier.  If you are new to hefe-weizen, this is a good place to start.  There are many some offerings better and many worse than Erdinger.
Robe blonde voilée surmontée d’une mousse blanche épaisse en dentelle qui persiste. Arômes légers de blé. Saveurs de blé, de bananes et de carton.

The whole grain family has been given a poor reputation.  The palpable splendor of meats, fruits, vegetables and of course sweets is simply too much for all the rices, oats, barleys and other grains out there that require time and temperance to be molded into something edible.  It’s true, grains need to be processed, but when they’re done right they make the very fabric of our culinary culture.  They’re old, tried and true, and for that reason they’re none too fashionable, but I think it’s that reliability that makes them the premier of the comestible world.  Sure, there is stuff like quinoa which by the only merit of having been untried makes it cool (even though it’s like chewing on dried pine needles and toe nail clippings) but we’re not talkin’ yuppy feed.  We’re talking about staples and the stuff that built civilization.  From that blessed and humble germ we made beer.  It was a monument to the grasses that sustained us (and no, not the recreational kind) and it was good.  It made men happy.  And from that drink we refined it to be an even cleaner, more chiseled testament to grain: the Hefe-Weizen.  Wheat incarnate in a drink, it epitomized the savory and the sweet.  But only if treated properly.  And sadly, the Erdinger attempt strays too far from that arcane ritual which produces exquisite Hefe-Weizen beer.  At its best I expect something replete with a well mannered wheatiness, plentiful banana esters and a good touch of vanilla.  In the Erdinger there is a dominant fuzzy palate that eclipses most of the flavors, which include a collection familiar to any household garbage can.  Stale apples, iron, cardboard, sawdust, a marzen-esque taste and weak nutmeg all work together towards a soft and flimsy palate.  It sounds like it should be wretched and offensive but en totale it’s a simple issue of failing to impress.  This golden drink bears some relation to its primordial plant form, but I’d expect it to ascend to a higher level of being after so much working and reworking of its inner carbohydrates, sugars and proteins.  So much work should produce at least some benefit, but I’d rather roll the grain and chaff around my hand and ponder on its meaning symbolism than give this botched beer another try.

Bottle.  Immediately on pour it did not have that hazy look to it... I could see through my glass, not a good sign.  Little aroma came through.  first taste, i was thinking, where is the flavor.  This was not the refreshing hefe that I appreciate.  Not a huge fan!

Bottle. W try it in Belgian Dash, Goiânia, Brasil. German Weiss with lesser personality that its similars for sale in the Brazilian stores. Haze yellow color with white head. Aroma is less fruity than another weissen biers, with yeast notes. Mild flavor of banana and yeast. Slightly sweet finish.

Well... everybody knows it. I used to like it. I drank it along with other weizen and it was almost tasteless.
But if you only get this around you... ok, at least it........

500 ml, aroma clementine weak, white head seems weak but stays, body cloudy of gray/orange/very  light bronze, taste hardly wheat, grapefruit, watery and some alcoholic which is strange for a hefe weiss, sweet. I wil never buy it again

Nicely hazy tangerine, big layer of soft white head. Soft rounded spice. Cloves, warm banana bread. Just a touch of butter on that banana bread. To my nose, the phenolic character in a weiss can get overbearing really easily, but this is the model of restraint. Sparkely, slighty tart flavor, fresh yeasty bread. The gentle tartness keeps things refreshing and bright, even lacking a perceptible hop contribution. Refreshing enough for summer, enough character that it doesn’t feel out of place in the middle of winter either.

One bottle from BOTW.  Had this one to celabrate the Cowboys win over the Giants(06).  Large white head on this disapated fast.  Not much of an aroma.  Flavor was wheat,yeast and banana.  I then added a squirt of lemon and became even more enjoyable and refreshing.
A classical German wheat beer. It has a mawkishly fruity taste. It is nicely to be looked. Well.

Hazy pale yellow beer with nice white head. Soft touch of boiled rice, bread dough, and some citric accents. Taste is very refreshing, and eazy drinking. It ends with a well integrated touch of lemon, and mellow hops.

From the 500ml bottle; fizzy white head, poured a reasonable pale gold which was clear until the yeast sediment swirl was added.  Smells of a spice vanilla.  The flavour is notable low-key...just the lowest touch of maltiness.  This doesn’t have enough to capture my taste buds to make me want more.  It passes for style.
bread, leather, cloudy, white foam, medium sweetness, light body, average carbonation, astringent,

500 ml bottle - pours hazy blonde with a nice head.  Aroma somewhat spicy with some banana and soft citrus notes.  Taste - your standard hefeweizen, nothing that really stands out, but not bad either....banana, some bitterness and yeast.  OK finish.  Everything about this beer screams "average".  Basic stuff.

16.9 oz bottle - Pours cloudy yellow with a light citrus and yeast aroma.  It tastes too bland.  Lively carbonation gives an okay mouthfeel, but it’s a little thin bodied.  The finish is refreshing.  The #1 hefeweizen in the world, huh?  They must mean in sales because it’s certainly not in quality.

At Pourhouse 50, 5 ounce sample. Light whitish colour with good creamy head, medium mouthfeel and creamy, lace in glass. Some smell of wheat but unfortunately the glasses are bleached out. Easy drinking but also ran wheat. Not all that much taste, but thirst quencher
Shared a bottle with Hans K....Pours with a grand head, disipatees med-slow..lacing is also quite good...subtle bitterness, mellow, pleasing but uninspiring.

This is a good German Bier, but not a great one.  Its that standard cloudy, pale amber Hefe Weisse colour, und has that typically thick frothy German head mit ein sweet taste.  However, I feel it lacks a little punch und flavour.  I drank this baby in a mini session mit ein Franziskaner Hefe-Weissbier und ein Schneider Weisse - I found the Erdinger the lesser of the three.  Overall - ziemlich gut!

Drank in the Erdinger Weissbrau glass.  Very thick unctuous off-white head. Cloudy yellow body.  Aromas of cranberries,  a little lemon, very malty on a side note of caramel and alcohol.  Fine, dry very balanced feel.  Flavors of alcohol, ginger, lemon and nice malts.  Very nourishing beer.

0.5 L bottle, ’bbe’ Apr 07. Dark golden with a fine turbidity and a small head that holds well. Yeasty and fruity aroma (hint of pineapple). Generous fruity (some citrus) taste with a light phenolic background and a spicy touch. It finishes rather quickly in soft and round toffee-like notes. Where is the aftertaste? Some more fruit and spices come retronasally. Nice, lively effervescence all around the mouth. Inoffensive; maybe a bit too much so.

[Floras kaffebar with the Roots]

A german pr-product for the masses. Tastes well at most football stadiums, but then nothing more. Reaches Maissels only to the ancles.
There is really nothing to write home about.  It tasted like a hefeweizen, but it was very bland.  Smooth, but definitely not memorable.

Bouteille de 500 ml achetée à la LCBO (Toronto, ONT). Arôme: Odeur d’agrumes et de coriandre. Apparence: La couleur est paille voilée avec une forte densité de bulle. Présence d’un large col mousseux et d’un fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût d’agrumes et de bananes avec une pointe d’épices. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est mince avec une texture minérale. Forte effervescence en bouche. Présence d’agrume en arrière goût. (Rating #736)

Light unparticular aroma.  Hazy, light golden body with generous beige head.  Very effervescent at first with OK lacing.  This hefeweizen is not like others I have sampled.  Maybe the bottle conditionning helped to tame the sometimes overpowering wheat taste found in others.  This wheat beer is somewhat lacking in flavor, but has a great refreshing, easy to appreciate quality about it as a reward.  As the beverage warms, the yeast flavor is unlocked and leaves a very pleasant and refreshing aftertaste in your mouth.  The mouthfeel is equally great.  Nicely carbonated, rich and dry finish.  I will definitely buy this one again.
Bottle. Thick head with a sweet aroma which I have a hard time pinning down exactly what it is. Taste is kind of disappointing... our local Denison’s Weissbier is much much better.

Øl (50 cl.) fået hos søster.

Øllen er tis-gul og ufiltreret. Har naturlig frugtagtig og gær smag som weizenbeer har og fylder godt i munden. Skummet er hvidt og tæt.

Duften er sødlig og en anelse gærret.

En af de lettere drikkelige weizenbeer jeg kender.

Big head, dissipating, slightly cloudy. Not much going on flavourwise, but it does offer some nice ones: bit of citrus, hint of yeast, subtle malts and a tiny modicum of dryness in the finish. It just needs way more of it. There are far beter weissbieren out there.

Poured a medium, white head, orange in color, very similar to blue moon in appearance. Nice aroma, taste has a semi-sweet flavor maybe citrus with a hint of clove or something of the sort. This hefe starts out mild and finishes uncommonly smooth. In my words, a decent hefe. What it lacks in flavor it makes up for in smoothness, defintely a beer to get if you come across it.
Poured a massive frothy head, thick orange looks and aroma, with notes of coriander.  Goes well with cheddar and rye biscuits.

Sampled with Stegosaurus and Beerded_one at Newtown Beerfest. Cloudy yellow pour and thick white head like any hefe should. Aroma of banan and mild wheat. Decent medium body but falls a bit short in taste for what I like in a hefe. TRY PALANER OR HACKER PSCHORR FOR A GOOD HEFE.
Bouteille de 500 ml. Jaune pale brumeuse, pas pire collet. Faible arome de blé avec un petit soupson de banane et d’épice. Goût de blé légé, peu épicé, mais assé rafréchissant.

One darn fine weißbier (white beer).  Physically, light in color and had a medium sized head when poured from the bottle.  Taste, outrageously smooth and, as you would expect with a white, suprising mild non-bitter aftertaste.  Certainly stands up to any white beer coming out of Belgium, and preferred over most.
Had the Hefe-Weizen DARK. Very nice, dark look. Pleasantly soft head. Good wheat and fruit flavors, balanced with right amount of alcohol.

Is it just me, or does the description make little to no sense?  Anyway, a decent hefe, nice hazy golden color, a little bit of stuff floating around that mostly settles to the bottom.  Aroma is ok, a little offputting.  Flavor is relatively bland and inoffensive, no wonder it’s the "World’s #1 Hefe-Weizen," according to the bottle.  A fairly forgettable brew.

On tap.  Cloudy dark yellow body. Medium white head. Light aromas of yeast, banana, orange and spices. Weak flavours; some grainy sweetness and a little citrus and spice.
A bit watery and thin.

Pours a cloudy yellow colour with a thick, foamy white head. Fruity and spicy taste. Very refreshing. Not much of an aftertaste though. . If you like Hefeweizen beers, give it a try, you’ll probably enjoy it. I sure did.

Draught at Wirstöms Sthlm. I don’t know if this particular sample suffered from poor handling by the clown in the bar or not, but I though this tasted horrible. Had a Carlsberg-house taste to it.. ie.. cardboard, DMS and skunk. Bleech.

Draft.  Suitably cloudy pour for a weissbier. Mostly a nice, light wheat beer smell. Taste is "compact:" malty but nicely modified by wheat.  A little citrus, but without the banana and spice overload of some hefes. Just enough bitterness to balance some sweetness.
Draught at The Volunteers on Baker St (London), a cloudy gold with a white foamy head. A wheaty aroma - banana and bubblegum. A goos spritzy mouthfeel, with strong bubblegum and berry flavours.

(Draught at Man in the Moon, Stockholm) Orange colour, hazy, with a huge white head. Fruity nose with notes of orange, Seville orange, cereal and some toffee. A bit restrained. Fruity taste with spicy notes of orange, banana and plum. Fairly dry, short finish. Well made and refreshing, but a bit restrained.
I might have had Erdinger Weissbier ocktoberf weizen but do not see that listed. Quite mediocre with poor aftertaste.
Cloudy golder wheat beer with huge white head. Citrus aroma, almost fruity. Easy mouthfeel, mildly yeasty

33cl bottle:  My least favorite of German Hefes that I have drank.  The aroma is somewhat lemony and crisp.  The flavor is lacking and the cloudiness wasn’t as beautiful and sparkly as other hefes.  Palate was also a bit thin.  Go for a Paulaner or Franizkaner.

Bottle Nose of grainy tartness. with a little banana, hazy gold with a small white head; flavor is wheaty with a little banana, and a little tartness in the finish. No date, but don’t think this bottle is very fresh.
Poured hazy golden with a large white head.  Taste was lightly acidic.  There isn’t much else to say but, I have to type something or it won’t take the rating.

First rating
(500 ml bottle at Henriksberg, Gothenburg) Shady light straw yellow color. Huge white creamy head. Small fruity scent, not as much banana as I’m used to, still fresh. Fresh typical wheat beer taste, fresh mouth feel. Sweet after taste. Low to no bitterness.
6/3/7/4/13=3.3

Rerate
50 cl bottle from Systembolaget, on June 2, 2009
Shady to cloudy yellow color, big fluffy white head. Banana and malty sweet scent and taste. Fresh moussy mouthfeel, low bitterness.
6/4/6/4/13=3.3

Draught (Bavarian Beer House EC1): Cloudy gold with a long lasting white head. Light banana and vanilla nose. Flavour has notes of bubblegum and vanilla, but is mostly just fresh grains. Simple wheat.

Erdinger Hefe-weizen
Pint bottle
Bottled Spring 05, consumed 09/06 (revisited 06/07, best before 01/08)
Medium pour in a pint glass, weizen

Poured a hazy gold with a large fizzy 1 inch mostly lasting white head.  Lively carbonation with small bubbles.

Smelt of yeasty dough and light orangey hops.

Taste was upfront light sweet oranges and slight bitterness, followed by a more pronounced orangey sweetness and a hint of flowery hops and bitter dough  in a short finish.  Mouthfeel was light, watery/dry, and overly fizzy.

Overall, an excellent yeasty German Hefe-Weizen that offers a lot on taste, although a bit hidden by the carbonation.  Revisit: A lot more refreshing on a hot summer day, but still fairly standard.
Revisit: more

Bottle from the LCBO. Hazy straw with a thick long lasting frotty head. Subltle aroma of wheat, yeast and bread. Taste is similar, with a hint of banana. Very smooth, with a  medium  body. Very good  for the style.

Very smooth, very clean and very sweet. This beer is definitely better than many (that I’ve had) in this style. I had several Hefe-Weizens before and they all tasted too strongly like bananas. I don’t really like that characteristic in my beer. This one does not go overkill on that; it does have that hint of banana but it is buried and subtle. This is incredibly sweet. WOW. It is sugar wheat sugar wheat sugar sugar wheat. It made me think instantly of sweet bread. I poured this slowly into my Weizen Glass, being careful not to include the yeast and sediment. On to the breakdown:

Appearance: Nice pale yellow with a hint of orange, huge sudsy head. Lots of tiny carbonation bubbles lasted the duration of the beer showing how active it is.

Smell: Sugar, wheat, vanilla, and just a hint of banana.

Taste: This is so amazingly sweet I was surprised. Wheat, malt, vanilla, banana and a variety of fruits are things I could pull out in this very well blended and balanced flavor. There is just a hint of hops in the crisp dry swallow. 

Mouthfeel & Drinkability: Wheat beers tend to be thin in my experience but this was not too thin. The sugar element along with the carbonation, helped it fill out into a satisfying medium body beer. It is very lightweight in your mouth and in your stomach. This makes it very easy to keep drinking more. I never had Erdinger Hefe-Weizen before, but for some reason I got 2 bottles. I just finished the second while writing this review, (I should have gotten a six-pack). Obviously a refreshing, drinkable beer. 

Hope this is helpful.
Cheers!

Nice yeasty and hoppy aroma with a hint of roasted grains and malt to it.  Not a real intense range of hefe-weizen-type flavors... some wheat, malt, hops even.  I didn’t think this was a truly great example of the style, in terms of the flavors.  No spiciness.  No clove.  No banana.  No bubblegum.  Not awful, but better choices exist.

bottle from asda, very nice beer to look at, seriously frothy head, very firm too and lasted almost down the whole glass. citrus on the nose but peach and yeast in the mouth, quite a complex beer to get to grips with but it turns out to be a very refreshing drink indeed
Pours a golden color with a thick frothy head. Aroma strong in yeast and lemon. Flavor is quick on the drawn with that yeast and lemon, followed by tones of orange, cloves, and dull wheat.

500ml bottle, 5.3% a/v
Pours with an unexpectedly large head which sticks around for the entirety, and a sexy opaque gold colour. The smell is yeasty and some citrus to e smelled. The taste is of some fruity notes such as peach and apricots, with a complex finish. Very nice mouthfeel.. This is a pretty good beer!
Bottle. Unclear yellow with huge head. Fruity and wheat aroma. Flavour is sweet of fruit and malt. Not the best weissbier, but it is still a great beer.

Hazy orange trumpet fizzing with sediment. Creamy white head. Suggestons of peach or apricot both in the aroma and flavour. Begins quite sourly, but ends with a bitter dryness. Refreshing interplay of fruit and wheat. Milkily still body. Slides down like flat lemonade after you’ve  guzzled a few. And at 5.3%, this one can sneak up on you. And your wallet. So be careful. Most expensive ’pint’ ever sampled in the British Isles (£4.20). 
(re-rate). Tastes like Honey Nut Loops. Atypically unfruity for a hefe. Woodsy aroma with slight almond. A bit dull, but refreshing.

What it lacks in Appearance (cloudy hefe-wiezen are not the best looking) it makes up for is aroma and taste. Pours a golden colour with a thick frothy head. Aroma a grains, citrus, and hint a spice(cloves). Taste is exactly what the aroma promises and is everything I love is a good Hefe. As alwaysw quite refreshing and a good end to a long work week. I will definitely search this one out again.
Bottle in Vodice, Croatia. This is one of the first Weissbiers I’ve actually enjoyed. Really white but strong too. Lots of foam and yeast/lemon aroma.

My new summertime favorite. Pours thick and shockingly white into a 1/2 liter hefe glass with a good head. Aroma hits you before the pour is even done. Aspects of hot biscuits, pizza dough and cloves. Little of the typical banana aroma. Taste was complex and mouthfeel was clean and lemony.

500ml Bottle: The bottle says it better than I could: ".. glistening golden-straw colour and majestic frothy head ..".  Pours as described, the head even stuck around until the end for me.  Aroma strong in yeast and lemon.  Flavour is quick on the draw with that yeast and lemon, followed by tones of orange, cloves, and a dull wheat.  Overall a decent hefeweizen; I’ve had worse, and I’ve had better.  I’d have it again.
This is a pretty decent wheat beer. I admit these are not my favorite style, but this isn’t bad. Perhaps a bit hoppy, but a relatively smooth finish. Wheaty and moderately sweet.

Aroma: malt, hops, fruity (apple), some ripe banana & cloves, slightly musty. 
 Appearance: yellow, cloudy, white head, orangetinged. 
 Flavor: bitter, mild, hops, some sweetness and sourishness, slightly watery, banana. 
 Palate: creamy, smooth.

Lately, I have been on a quest to find the perfect Hefe-weizen.  This unfortunately, is not it.   I dont smell much, and certainly do not pick up any banana or clove, as others have mentioned.  At any rate, it looks nice, and doesn’t taste bad, just not as good as other hefe’s I have had lately.  This has lots of wheats going on, but that’s about it.  Reminds me of an American wheat beer.  Pretty good on a hot summer day, but overall, a little weak.

Bottle. Cloudy orange with a huge head. Banana and yeasty aroma. Hints of grass. Sweet banana flavours, drier towards the finish with spices becoming more prominent. Sparkling, good grainy  mouthfeel. Good summer beer.

Bottle, 500ml. A cloudy pale yellow coloured pour with a huge white head. Aromas of sweet orange, banana and wheat. Not a huge amount of wheat in the flavour, but there is more banana and a nice maltiness in the background. Moderate sweetness. Alcohol becomes noticable as it warms up. A light sweet finish with some cardboard notes. High carbonation. Not just another boring wheat beer - the malt makes this one stand out from the crowd.

Bottled. Cloudy, carbonating, orange beer with big creamy head. Weak aroma, with ripe bananas, cloves, some citrus and yeast. A bit thin in the mouth, with spices, yeast, citrus and some wheat in the flavor. Could use a bit "more of everything". Long spiced finish with some bitterness but nice refreshing.

Pours bright creamy yellow.  Abundant, thick, lasting head.  Cloves and citrus aroma.    Nothing exciting after that.  Very mild tasting, with no palate action or aftertaste.  An easy drinker, but a little disappointing.

From a twelve ounce bottle at my buddy Mike’s art opening - This one pours a golden, white-headed weissbier that’s more clovish than banana-ish in its aroma. A complex tadte with a full palate, this is a fine beer.

This German Hefeweizen pours a slightly hazy gold color from a 500ml bottle. Large sized white foamy head with strong lacing. Aroma is malty and fruity and not very estery. A medium to light bodied Hefe. Malts are fruity and sweet but the lack the banana and clove esters. Light and refreshing but seems to be more of a wheat than a hefe. Its missing that fruitiness and the soft fluffy mouthfeel. Lively carbonation. Clean and smooth. There is a touch of that banana and clove at the finish, but just a touch and it comes in way too late. Kind of bland tasting. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Draught.  Pours moderately cloudy yellow with a noticeable carbonation and a nice white head.  Aroma is mildly of yeast, wheat, spice, and a bit of banana.  Flavor is the same components, slightly stronger.  Finish is moderately long and a little spicy.  Fairly good; a middle-of-the-road German hefeweizen, but could use a bit stronger flavor and aroma.

Poured the nice cloudy yellow with a large white head. Looked very nice in my Paulaner weiss glass. The aroma was very faint of banana and spice. Flavor was also lacking, too watery. Too thin is a good way to put it. Middle of the road German hefe, certainly not at the top of its class.

Bottled. Cloudy, carbonating, orange beer with a large, off-white head.  Weak aroma, with ripe bananas, cloves, some citrus and yeast. A bit thin in the mouth, with spices, yeast, citrus and some wheat in the flavor. Could definately use a bit "more of everything". Long spiced finish with some bitterness. Refreshing, but not worth seeking out again. (060723)
Bottle. orange colour with a white head. Aroma is light banana, yeast and citrus. Flavour is the same. An ordinary weissbier
Thick and murky. Medium nose with a hint of citrus, but not served with lemon. Medium thick head that fades fast. Bitter on tip ot tongue, thick and bready finish.
Bottle. Cloudy yellow with big white head. Hint of green apples in aroma. Rather sweet. Not the best of weissbiers.

Pours cloudy honey color, nice white head. Aroma is light with weak orange charcter and yeast primarily. Boring, refreshing and highly drinkable is the best way to describe this one. It’s simple, with predominant yeast flavor and wateryness with slight orange in background. Not a great hefeweiss, too simple.

500ml bottle - Not bad, but not great...for weissbier I would have like a lot more...uhm...weiss-ness from it. I found it a little thin and one dimentional. There are some good flavours in there but they’re afraid to get up and announce themselves. The head on this thing was huge. Not bad, but...meh. There are so many better beers out there in this style.

Great looking pour for the style, a hazy straw body with a huge rocky head.  The aroma is pretty much of an equal balance between fresh banana and a wheaty tartness with a dash of clove thrown in for snicks.  Spritzy in the mouth.  It tastes of spiced up wheat with a little banana, an inkling of bubblegum, clove, and a small lemon twist.  Gassy, but not bad.

Binny’s Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL

Not bad.... for one of my favorite styles.  The pour is an indicative yeasty-cloudy haze, although this sampling contains some actual grain sediment to the bottom of the glass (almost like tobacco flakes - not a good "quality control" sign from the get-go).  It has a tremendous head with decent retention and nice webbed spiderlace.  The nose consists of light aromas of bubblegum, lemon and bananas (carmelized, maybe?).  Flavors are similar, but MUCH lighter, with banana, slight bubblegum and lemon notes.  Honestly, I wish the flavors were a bit stronger for the brew... With the (almost) seltzer mouthfeel, this feels like a "hefe-light".  The body just doesn’t stack up to the initial pour and bouquet.  Again, not a bad beer, but just not the most complex for the style.

A cloudy, lemony yellow coloured beer with a strong but frothy white head. A light, citrusy nose, wheaty, then a hint of spice and malt in the finish. The taste is a little weak on the mouth. Dry, cereal flavours, along with a citrusy bite, then the malty spiciness comes through. The finish is dry. Good, but certainly not the greatest weissbier i’ve tasted. Bottle, kindly donated to the cause by Mark @ The Fox & Hounds, Heacham, Norfolk).
bottle. slightly murky pale yellow color. big creamy head. too carpy for my taste. not very weiss beer like. if you want weissbeer choose something else.

Pours with a generous, somewhat rocky, foamy, mostly small bubble, white head. Aroma of wheat, phenol(clove), ester(banana, lemon), and bready malt.  Appearance is darker yellow with a orange tinge.  Flavor sharper flavor of a traditional hefe.  Still has the banana, very faint hint of clove, lemon, pith, and slight presents of hops just to balance out the flavor.  Palate has prickly carbonation, more watery than creamy mouth feel, and a medium body.

This Weiss is on the weaker end of the flavor spectrum.  Thin white head dissapears quickly. The Bavarian purity laws are a bunch of hogwash... like all other beer is bad? Not nearly in the class of the others.
Pours a golden color with a white head.  It is clear so it is filtered.  Not too strong of a wheat aroma.  Slight clove flavor with just a little banana.  Very smooth.

For the bronze final in the FIFA World Cup on Saturday eve (08.07.2006) on TV, I picked two German beers. During the first half I had 500ml of Erdinger Weissbier. Creamy white head. Hazzy yellow. Fresh, but light wheat aroma. Rich banana flavour combined with grain and notes of yeast. Soft carbonation. Overbearingly sweet. Straightforward. And no scores at the Gottlieb-Daimler- Stadion, so I went for a stronger beer...

This is a very good beer.  I purchased it from a local beer and wine shop called the Cellar.  I think I have a taste for wheat beers and this was by far a good beer.  I also noticed that this beer leaves a very good lingering aftertaste.
Cloudy orange, rocky off white head.  Overipe pear aroma.  Cloves, banana, low carbonation.  Not a lot of flavor.  Smooth finish.
A pretty decent wheat beer but probably the least complex wheat beer I have tried.

At several pubs in Germany.   Cloudy and a nice rocky white head, as expected.  I find this beer  to have the leaset  banana and clove aroma and flavor of all that I have had.  Very distinctive whaet grain aroma and flavor dominate, much like an american wheat beer.

Light golden head.  Soapy nose with bananananananas.  Classic bready yeast banananananananananana puree with a touch of chalk.  Very full in the mouth with lively carbonation.  Stylistically bland, lacking in spice, and featuring some off flavors.

Tasted 11/06/2006, with Fritha. 500ml bottle from Island Bay New World.
Murky yellow-gold.  Pure white head balloons out of the glass in a classic germen weizen style, then thins significantly and lingers.  Laces slightly; champagne effervescence.  Wheat and slightly worty on the nose, with gentle spicy esters.  More wheat in the mouth, with sweet lolly malt; spicy esters and tart malt dominate the middle, with banana, candi and cloves in the finish.  Strong carbonation, quite prickly, with a light-medium weight.  Polished and good drinking but not entirely inspiring.  Maybe it’s just time for a palate rest - a few days without beer.
500ml bottle. Very honey-like colour. Very nice honey aroma. The taste is a bit more bitter, but with a sweet finish.

Frothy head atop a hazy body with visible carbonation. Palate and body is a bit thin. Nose and flavor are a template of the usual hefe characteristics: some clove, banana, chewy yeast and appetizing quality. This being said, it is all a bit muted. Maybe due to freshness, or just not one of the top tier hefes. Enjoyable in a prosaic way.
Not much smell or cloudiness.  German wheat beers are so much better than American ones. Still, one can only get so excited about the style. A little banana in it. Not bad, but not amazing.
A low citrusy aroma is detectable.  The pour is a cloudy yellow with a small white head.  The flavor has some citrusy quality with a light dry finish on the palate.

This one poured with the typical huge head and standard cloudy yellow appearance. However, the aroma was lacking any bananas and cloves with only a note of citrus. Flavor followed suit, altough some level of spicing did come through (not sure what it was). A nice wheat beer, but sure to be beaten.

Pours cloudy golden with a small white head.  Aroma was weak but there were some hints of banana and cloves plus a bit of breadiness.  Taste was watery at first followed by hints of banana and lemon.  Not much going on with the palate.  I wanted banana and lemon and I did not get that here.  Not a bad Hefeweizen but I’ve had quite a few better ones.

Pours a very hazy golden with a smaller white head that did not really retain.  Aroma of sweet malt, lemon, wheat, banana bread and cereal. A bit light compared to others of the same style.  Flavor of citrus, pilsner malt, cereal, tingly carbonation.

(0.5L Bottle) Pours hazy with think white head. Aroma is somewhat lacking compared to other similar Hefeweizens. Also lacks some of the fruity flavoring. All in all, not bad... but nothing special either.
This was an alright hefeweizen although I didnt think It was outstanding.  White foamy head, opaque dark yellow body and a very yeasty aroma.

makes a very good breakfast mixed with banana juice (like nearly all hefe-weizen)
btw. this is a common habit in Germany

had it in a restaurant on saturday
white head lasts  well
yellow,slightly hazy color
smells yeasty,a bit malty, clove smell,a bit of citrus smell,some weak banana
tasts  yeasty,there are some clove,some hops,a little bit of fruit
in the aftertaste some hops,clove,bread,a little bit of fruit
not bad,but a bit weak in his aromes i know other hefeweizen with more,stronger flavours

Light golden color; so saturated with tiny, frothy bubbles that the beer looks murky for a while after the pour; lovely, frothy, two-finger head that diminishes but hangs around as a ring for a very long time.  Nose is mild, with citrus and yeast.  Flavor is the weak point, with just barely the tiniest touch of citrus, and a lingering wheat aftertaste.  Medium-light body, clean, frothy.  I wish the flavors were stronger, but this is better than I expected.

Aroma/Malty-light,
Appearance Head/large,
Head/Color-white,
Head/Longevity-fully diminishing, Body/Hue-cloudy,
Palate Body/light
Clear effervescent gold color with a huge fluffy white head. Aroma is citric wheat. Flavor is very clean very refreshing. Light citric, very nice.

Hazy yellow with huge white head (Be careful when pouring) Taste and smells of a bit Citrus and of course wheat. The finish is a bit sweat and all around very pleasant!  Re-rating aug 2007. from 3,5 - 3,2.... This is not even in he best category!

I was expecting a lot more from this one, seeing the pour from the bottle. Perfect hazy yellow/orange colour with a GREAT white head. Aroma was decent, as was the flavour. Citrus was more powerful than the beer flavour itself.
Hazy yellow with a 3 finger head. This is a subtle easy to drin hefeweizen. Doesn’t suck but nothing really stands out. Good "lawn mower" beer.
Hazy orange color with a thin white head. Sweet wheat and banana aroma. Sweet fruity and banana flavor.
Hazy yellow colour, white head.  Sweet corny scent.  Gentle musty wheat taste.  Quite nice really.

i’d always avoided this since it’s so poorly rated here.  after drinking it, i can only guess it’s poorly rated because people don’t like flavor in their hefeweizens.  why is that?  sweet taste, lots of fruit.  some citrus, most of the things you normally want in a hefe.  RERATE.  flavorless weiss.  no banana.  everything else is pretty standard.
Bottle: Yellow body, nice creamy foam. Aroma og banana, and sweet malt. Have also a little bit of citrus. Light body, and almost nothing bitternes in the finish. Tasted almost like a light lager.
Bottle. Huge creamy white head with good duration. Color is hazy golden. Aroma is wheat malt. Taste is crisp and sweet.

Cloudy golden body; large,white, long lasting head with excellent lacing; average bubbles with high density.
Moderate malty and yeasty aroma. Notes of banana and apple; light citrus.
Moderate sweet malty flovour, with an acidic note that becaomes more important after a while. Finsh is lightly bitter at the beginning, then sweetnes is dominant.
Good beer; flavour is softer (less acidic) than in other hefeweizen.

16.9 oz bottle Best before 2/06. A little past it’s prime.

Cloudy yellow with a voluminous white head. On the initial pour the head extended a full two fingers above the rim of the glass without collapsing down the sides. Left no lacing as it dissipated.

Not much aroma, one has to really agitate the beer to get even the slightest hint of banana.

Flavor is light wheat, a little spice, a little lemon drop. 

finish is light and clean. 

Overall kind of boring.
Not bad overall, very comparable to Widmer’s weissbier - Very enjoyable and drinkable, mild malty-wheat flavor. Very average overall - good but not special.

Almost non-existent aroma, maybe some wheat.  Big frothy head and a cloudy gold body.  Smooth and sweet flavor but the bubblegum and banana is noticeably absent.  Still a refreshing beer, but not the best hefe.
Pours orange with big white top. Nor bitter nor sweet. Yeasty aroma, however not as fruity as I had expected. Overall a very nice weissbier though.
Thick white lacy diminishing head. Hazy orange apperance. Clove, slightly metallic nose. Hont of banana.

Tap.  Cloudy and bright golden / pale orange in color with a booming, frothy, whipped white head that’s one-inch tall.  Freshly kneaded honey dough, some light lemon detergent, a sourdough scratch, cloves and pepper neither gain nor lose ground in the aromatic portion.  Light biscuit dough taste comes out early.  Yeast is the champion here, paring with sweet honey dough and a buttery nectar / honeycomb quality.  Carbonation is perfectly titillating while some lemon cleanser and mild floral traits pepper lily leaves, while an ever distant cardamom characteristic brings up the rear.  Ever so mild, sweet lemon grahams and a balking vanilla tootsie roll dimension round out the waxy, lively mouth feel.  Margarine and Ricolla lemon drops leave a slightly distressing mark in the finish.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma of wheat and citrus. Flavor is sweet, wheat, citrus, and fruit.

Pale yellow, cloudy with tall white head. ..	Clovey esters, light. .. ..	Thin flavor, not too much in the way of yeastiness.  Sweet finish. .. .. .	Light Body. .. .. 	Pretty average weissbier, not too exciting. . …

A native German friend of mine told me this was his favorite beer when I asked about the best one to try and given our general different tastes in beer in general, I had some doubts, but one taste and I had to admit this was one of the best beers I had yet tasted.  I’ve since tried a half dozen other hefe-weizens and Erdinger is still the smoothest and most plesant tasting one I’ve tried to date.

Brown bottle, drank in its own glass, expiry date:06-2006, purchase date: November 7, 2005; eye: pale yellow, good effervescence, nice white head that disappears rapidly; nose: faint aroma overall but detected the presence of malt, wheat and some spices; mouth: nice carbonatation, the first hit comes from the malt but then not a whole lot more, lightly sweet, relatively long finale all in its mild bitternes, makes me salivate a lot, thin to medium body, aerial texture

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 500 ml, bue dans son verre, date de péremption : 06-2006, date d’achat : 7 novembre 2005; oeil : jaune pâle, claire, bonne effervescence, mousse blanche qui disparaît rapidement; nez : odeurs faibles, malt, froment, épices; bouche : bonne carbonatation, un premier coup provient du malt mais c’est à peu près tout, légèrement sucrée, finale relativement longue toute en légère amertume, beaucoup de salive, corps de léger à moyen, texture aérienne
lite yellow color on the pour, as mentioned many times below.  a nice citrusy bite with a subtle wheat toned aroma.  decent head.
0,5l bottle, clowdy yellow with tastes of citrus and clove, nice head. easy drinkable and probably between the top ten of german hefe weizen.

On tap: Pours a cloudy golden color with hints of orange that has a medium size frothy off-white head. Aroma is wheat with hints of citrus and lemon. Initial flavor is sweet and fruity leaving a mild bitter finish. The watery body make it easy drinking but not very enjoyable.

My guess is that this is the "Pyramid" of Germany when it comes to beer.  Pours hazy gold with a decent head.  Lemony aroma with some yeast.  Taste was pretty flat, some wheat, some citrus, but really watery.  Get something else.

Had a 16 oz. draft. Poured a golden orange, with a nice head at first, that unfortunately dissipated very quickly. Hazy appearance and a citrus-lemon aroma. Decent tasting and okay finish, but nothing spectacular about this beer, but then, I’m not much of a Hefe fan in general.
Bottle. Pours hazy golden with a three finger thick white head. Aroma of wheat and citrus. Flavor is sweet, wheat, citrus, and slight fruit. Weak body, ok brew.

Amber clowdy yellow. Persistent head, creamy aspect, with medium sized bubbles. Some dispersed bubbles go to the top slowly. Soflty citric aroma, a bit fruit aroma. Pleasing citric taste. In the aroma, get clearer a fresh cereal barley background. Thin, almost like water, astringent.

I don’t know why, but I’ve been drinking a fair number of German wheats lately. This one was average at best compared to its peers. Hazy yellow, big fizzy head. Not a great deal of aroma-- maybe some faint banana. Palate was also fizzy, and on the watery side. Muted flavours of banana and spice. It was okay.

Slightly cloudy, pale straw body with enormous, glass filling, white head. The aroma is light, mostly wheat, very little Hefe yeast, maybe a touch of bubblegum. The flavor is much better, apple, cinnamon, clove, and a touch of banana. The mouthfeel is light and smooth with high carbonation and a slightly bitter finish.

a good standard hefe here.  bottled. pours typical mealy yellow with a billowy white head.  notes of apple and spice in the nose. bubblegum flavors dance on a wheatesque palate of german yeasties and biscuits.
Light yellow colour, amber teint, muddy body. Small stable white creamy head. Intense hoppy aroma, citric (lemon), wheat. Initial light spicy flavour, hoppy long-during nice finish.

Yellowish with a tinge of orange pour includes a billowing white head.  Scent is wheat, lemon, slightly metallic, and banana and clove (faint).   Taste has a definite citrus element to it with subtle wheat notes, banana again with light spices.  Palate is light, bubbly and rather thin.  An Okay Hefeweizen, this wouldn’t be my first choice if I was looking for a Hefe, but it does refresh and is very drinkable.

Bottle: Hazy, pale golden coloured, huge creamy white head, slowly diminishing; faint sourish fruity (citrusy) nose, only weak traces of bananas, a bit yeasty, too, slightly sweetish flavour, sticky mouthfeel; short, sweetish and fruity finish. a pretty bland and boring Weizen, NOT refreshing, NOT well drinkable. The equivalent to Warsteiner in the world of Weizen..........................

0.5L bottle, personally shipped from Germany. Opened to celebrate arrival of my beer & wine shipment. Poured into Erdinger Hefeweizen glass (of course). Lasting, fluffy white head atop a cloudy yellow-amber body. Nice aroma of fruit, some spices, and grains. Good flavors - mainly light fruit and grain notes. Not overly carbonated, but a little lively with a nice, smooth finish. I’ll cry when this case is gone. Well done!

1. On Tap at the Crescent, Salford 02/04/2004
Golden coloured with a cloudy appearance. Slightly rich on the palate. Some sour fruit aroma and dryness in a lasting finish.
2. On Tap at the Borough Arms, Crewe 30/06/2005
Golden coloured with a cloudy appearance. Creamy on the palate. Some sour fruit floral and hop aromas..Pleasant finish.
3. On Tap at the Crescent, Salford 30/06/2007
Hop aroma. Golden coloured and hazy in appearance. Fruity and floral with some alcohol present. Crisp and slightly dry malt finish.
Bottle 0.5l. Bright golden - almost yellow. Hazy. White head disappearing rather quickly. Too carbonated. Hardly any smell or taste. Disappointing

50cl bottle. Poured an unattractive murky yellow-tan into a footed pilsner glass with a towering white bubbly head (moderately diminishing). Aroma is almost nonexistent but what there is is quite plesant: spicy & fruity with some yeast and DMS. Flavor is also nearly absent. Bitter with some grain and DMS. No finish at first, eventually a short, sweet & buttery finish. Flat, watery palate. Inoffensive but boring, boring, boring.

On tap at the Hessen Haus during the 2006 Crescent Moon Beer Bus Trip. Cloudy yellow gold with a fluffy white head. Aroma is fantastic of cloves, bananas, and lemons. I could just sit and sniff this beer all night. Flavor is yeasty, tangy and seriously carbonated. Awesome head retention- the last gulp was a big ol’ blob of white foamy head. 1/13/9- On tap at the Huber Haus. very refreshing with an outstanding amount of yeast for vom fas. Delicious.

Bottle.
Hazy yellow coloured with a white head.
Aroma of fruits spices and yast.
Watery flavour with notes of fruits and spices.
Fizzy palate.
Boring and overrated !

Bottled @Mandai Orchid Gardens, Singapore

Pale hazy yellow, big creamy head, collapsing quite quickly. Lemony, a bit metallic nose. Crisp, lemony, mild banana notes. Quite bland German hefeweizen.

I understand Bavarian purity laws. With that said,  this brew is great in comparison to mass produced lagers. But this is not a lager, no, it’s actually a dissapointing, extremely light version of a German weissbier. Looks like Hefe-weizen, drinks like water w/ a splash of lemon. Enough said.

according to the back of the back label this is the "worlds #1 Hefe-Weizen", lets see if it stands up to the boasting.
The aroma is very very weak compared to most German hefes I have had, what there is is slightly estry and green apple sweet .
Appearance is par for the course for hefes, hazy light orange with a nice pure white head
Taste is a let down very pedestrian..slightly wheaty and bubbly carbonation..with a slight tang of estery type yeast
Pretty much average on the palate for the style
 I found this rather boring an not even as good as Paulaner Hefe..its certainlly not #1 in quality..must be in sales.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy orange color with a long lasting frothy head.  A little yeasy fruity aroma, not real strong though.  Flavor was also a little yeasty.  Not much different than other German Hefeweisen.  Not bad at all though.
Bottled. Hazy light yellow, bubbly white head. The aroma is fruity and wheaty. The flavour has a taste of wheat and fruits. You can feel the moderate carbonation. There is a sweetish after taste.
Bottle.Hazy gold with a medium head,aroma is spicey,taste is of banana,sweet malt and wheat.
Nice, creamy, slightly hazy rich, huge and rich head. When I want hefe, erdinger is my first and only choice for now

canIt smells strongly of fruits and lime citrus. it also has some toasty notes and hints of cooked vegetables (though not in an unpleasant way). It has a frothy white head that leaves a good lacing and a white film on the top. It is of a murky light yellow color, like that of a papaya frui. It tastes sweet with some bitter notes. Its body is light to medium and its carbonation lively, making it a smooth and nice beer
This is for me the referance point of German style hefe-weizen. Huge head, not a very characteristic type, I prefer other hefe weizen
this brew maks you feel like you have a fairy that stole your keys and you cant go outside because he might have also taken your shoes.

Bottle. Very weak nose, mild malty flavors, and marginal fruitiness. More like the semblance of a wheat beer than an actual flavorful brew.  Nothing offensive, suprising, or unappetizing - just boring.

Bottle: Dark straw, moreso heavy haze than cloudy, huge rocky white head, spotty lacing, moderate carbonation. &nbsp Slightly sour wheaty aroma, not much evidence of clove or banana. &nbsp Wheaty tongue, slight tartness, but none of the banana and clove of others. &nbsp Slight sweetened melon tho. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate, and nowhere near as full as other Weizens. &nbsp Seems almost moreso like an American version without the sulphur. &nbsp Finishes with a soft wheaty tartness. &nbsp Not complex, pretty straight forward, not bad, but not terribly interesting either. &nbsp I would prefer Paulaner or Weihenstephaner to this one any day.

Poured a cloudy yellow with a BIG head with some staying power. Nice lacing was left when the head subsided. Aroma was yeasty, bread with a touch of banana. Flavor was of yeast with a slight bitterness. Good but not great in my book.

Bottled. Golden to straw yellow pour with a huge frothy white head - looks fantastic.  Unusual for a wheat beer, and even moreso for a Hefe, it’s clear and not cloudy.  Strong carbonation.  Wheaty and hoppy aroma but no fruit esters in the nose.  Significantly hoppier taste than expected, light bodied, and bland.  I was expecting so much more!  We’re really not supposed to grade to style here, and that plays in the Erdinger’s favor, as it’s  a failure of its style; no, stacked up against all the beers of the world, it’s merely bland and unexceptional. [2006.01.24: 2.1]

Had several bottles over the years, this one fresh an in the States.  Still an odd nose, strongly wheaty, but this one loaded with esters, especially banana.  Light and quenching bitterness, beautiful quick bready resolution that lasts, generally nice yeast contributions, refreshing.  Doesn’t really have any guaiacol, and has never been the cleanest of Weissbiere, but I’ve really come around on its possibilities.  [2014.11.10: 3.4]

Bottle. Pours golden, and my sample was not cloudy, and very carbonated! Old bottle perhaps. Not much banana clove aroma, it was more malty. Same with the taste. Finish and flavor had  little sweetness. I think this bottle was past its prime, so I am going to try and revisit this one IF I CAN FIND ANOTHER BOTTLE, so admins,  don’t rip on me in the forums.

Poured into a weizen glass, it’s appearance is a rather murky and somewhat light yellow and orange - soft in appearance, initially with a large, billowy head that slowly shrinks down into a thin white layer, without much lacing, disappointingly.  The nose is sweet banana, clove and mandarin oranges.  Sugars and esthery spices from the yeast give this hefeweizen a profoundly fruity, sharp aroma.  Initially it’s lightly sweet, somewhat lacking a depth of flavors, and it rolls over the tongue like olive oil - very slick and somewhat watery.  Dare I say this is a bland beer after having it smell so wonderful?  With a light but harsh roughness to the palate, it finishes empty and leaves me wanting something further.  An OK wheat beer, with a geniune aroma that drives anticipation, but in the end it shows itself as a pretender.

Bottle. White lasting head. Golden unclear body with quite a good deal of carbon dioxide. Banana aroma with a sharp edge. Guess this was a bit too cold because normallly the flavor is relatively sweet. This time bitterness was dominant.

(12.29.05) One pint, 0.9 fl oz brown bottle purchased from DiCarlo’s, Mundelein, IL.  5.3% ABV. Hazy golden weisse beer having a large long-lasting white head with good lacing. No discernable carbonation.  Honey and spicy clove aroma.  Medium bodied that starts with light malt sweetness and spicy clove flavor. Crisp finish with pleasant malt aftertaste. An enjoyable, clean tasting and palette refreshing brew.

straight from the cellar of my girly friend stephiäs haus. Cloudy haze pour witha  big beige head. semi smooth stingy citrus and malt banana bread taste. yum. very easy going brew, though nothing too special. but zes, it be enjoyable yo. no real big yeast fest though.

50 cl bottle. Yeast at the bottom. Cloudy yellow colour with a big thich head. Nice aroma of bread, banana and some yeast. Also hints of banana in the flavour with wheat and yeast, quite good, but not great.
Cloudy yellow colour with a medium mostly lasting head. Aroma of hobs. Nice fruity taste with hints of citrus.
Bottle. Hazy yellow in colour. White long lasting head. Weak aroma of wheat. A little sweet malty aroma with some citrus and banana hints. Not one of the best weissbier out there.
Best Hefe-Weizen that I have ever tried, because this one, in difference to many other wheat beers, leaves your stomach undamaged.
Despite it being an easy-to-get beer, it’s not undeserved of its success. A very strong flavour og wheat, that makes it a soft drink that always refreshes.

Best before end 12/2005 bottle consumed on 12/16/2005.  Pours a hazy copper-goldenrod color.  Slightly muted in tone, not as shimmering and light-tinted as the style demands, I believe.  The head is initially large and fluffy (white), well-retained, but lacking any lacing.  Carbonation is seemingly low, and only sparse bubbles rise lazily to the surface.  Aroma:  Very dry wheat.  Creamy, lightly biscuity, with white sourdough and just a faint pinch of lemon juice.  Bananas are noticeable, but are weak and drowned out in the strong yeast dryness and even stronger wheat dryness.  Just bland and doughy.  No lively bubblegum, clove or citrus zest and no trace of any honey-like malts.  A touch salty and rather stale smelling.  Very weak in strength as well.  Flavor seems to confirm that this bottle is either A) much passed its prime (though it is still within in the best before date) or B) not a well-made weisse.  I’d hope to think the former.  The low carbonation seems to be a good indicator that perhaps this has been heated too much at some point and sat out for too long a period of time.  Doughy, lightly grainy malts are briefly sweet, but passing completely to a strong wheat creaminess in texture brought on by a huge dry wheat flavor.  Bit more of saltiness/seltzer water.  Sponge bread, hint of bananas and lemons.  No clove, hops or bubble gum and the mouthfeel is sluggish, the texture loose.  No alcohol apparency.  Would like to try a fresher bottle for sure.  4/4/5/2/8
Draught weizen glass at Beacon Street Pub. on 6/22/07
Much improved, so I’m going to change the rating to reflect this experience.  Must have been too old a bottle previously.  This still showed a golden-hay colored body with a moderate amount of head, light lacing.
Wheaty with soft honey, lemon and light bubble gum.  Not your typical blast of bubble gum or clove and not all that doughy or yeasty (in terms of actual yeast blandness, not ester production).  Probably filtered and then redosed with yeast?  I dont know.  The flavor was fairly estery, but without any real acidity/doughiness, and mostly a chewy, hay-like flavor from the wheat and barley.  Interesting, refreshing and a nice, light, drinkable rendition.  Clean, with a fair amount of wateriness, but nothing out-of-style.

12oz bottle pours golden with a fair white head that stays pretty well.  Aroma is well pretty much nothing.  A little bread...  Flavor is light citrus.  A touch of bananna and clove and a bit of lemon.  Palate is light an airy.  Not my favorite style and this was subpar even for the style.

Lots of carbonation, thick head, medium soure,.some banana and bisquit, quit nice 
re rate wrong tempature.

Shows a hazy beautiful yellow color with a big white and fizzy head, long lasting. When it finally diminishes it leaves a medium lacing. Light aroma, a little citric with some cereal notes. Slightly sweet and soft flavor with hints of lemon. Short astringent finish. Little aftertaste. The carbonation is high and refreshing. No alcohol noticeable. Enjoyable, yet nothing impressive.
I really enjoy Erdinger, don’t have the chance to drink it all too often, nice golden appearance, enjoyable aroma and taste

Large white foamy head. Golden colour. Smalle aroma of yeast and a little malt. Lots of carbonation. Flavour of wheat, lemon and some bananas.A<little watery. Fairly aftertaste. Good in a hot summers day.

Ultra smooth, I first had this Hefe in San Francisco at a great asian resturant, The Slanted Door, It was on tap. I looked for it when i returned to Ohio. It was just as good from the bottle. Creamy, foggy, low acidic, pale golden with a medium head. This beer has a great finish absolutely no after taste.
Drink it cold.
Pours a hazy yellow with a decent white head. In the beginning quite bitter, but gets sweeter as it is aerated in the glass. Aromas of wheat and yeast. Medium bodied. Sour/bitter finish.

This is the beer that made me fall in love with quality brewing.  The taste is nothing too special but the smoothness that this beer is second to none.  It has a nearly creamy taste.  When poured right and at the right temperature this beer is fantastic.
On tap (Kulminator-Antwerp) Unclear blond colour, large white head. fruity aroma, some citrus. Full body clear taste, some herbs. I like this one a lot.

Just drank a pint thanks to a recommendation by a friend, slowly becoming my favourite style of beer, this is a very nice brew. Don’t half give you a bit of a quick foggy head feeling though. It’s hazy light coloured beer with a sweet aroma, summery fruity, there is a slight bitter finish but in all very smooth, the taste is not as strong as some. Good quaffable beer.
foggy apple juice, carbonation bubbles growing with a froth ive never seen, apple banana nose, dissapointment dont buy it

Hazy yellow hue, with a frothy white head, yeasty, fruity banana-like accent, grainy, wheat aroma, follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a yeasty, fruity note of banana, pale malt, smooth wheaty character, leading towards a zesty crisp acidic finish.

This one pours a cloudy yellow colour with a bright white head. The first scents that come to mind are fruit, maybe  ripe pear and apples? Very carbonated to the nose. First sip was thin and watery.  The flavours are a little fruity also with not much carbonation to the taste. Smooth because its so thin but not bad over all. The finish is not as strong as other Wheat beers but thin also.

First of all, could they get someone who speaks English to write the Commercial Description?!  Secondly, there is just something about an unfiltered hefe.  What a great style of beer.  This one has a big rich foamy head that has some staying power.  There are hefes that are  cloudier but this is a handsome beer.  It is smooth in the mouth, slightly tart and not at all bitter.  It tastes a lot like its style.  Plenty of sweet lemon and just a hint of banana.  Very enjoyable, but not a standout in its style.
Big lasting head, cloudy, yellowy colour. Soft aroma and flavour - only slightly fruity, creamy. Delicious
slight yeast and wheat aroma.  cloudy yellow with medium head.  wheat, apple, and banana in flavor.  light bodied.  kind of sour and needs more carbonation..

On tap at the Octoberfest in Helen. This was before the clubbin holmes. A yellowish appearance with a large head. Kind of session like with not much going on in the flavor department. A slight banana and clove flavor. The mouthfeel is somewhat thin with an aftertaste of wheat bread. Not bad. Cheaper on tap than the damn Amstel Light and Heine, score!!

(Bottled) Opaque, paleish-orange color with a huge, foamy head. Very bubblegum-fruity-estery aroma with yeast and lots of lemon and orange. Orange-fruity flavor with surprisingly little banana in it. Feels like a mixture of German Hefeweizen and Belgian Witbier, with a sip of Abbey Triple. Light to medium-bodied, very refreshing palate with a bit foamy but smooth carbonation. Definitely lighter and easier to drink than most Hefeweizens. A very nice thirst-quencher, but definitely not complex. I can see why this has its fans.
Love the deep, murky look of a good hefe. Lots of sweet malt and allspice flavor. Very creamy and smooth with light hints of banana and citrus. Pretty tasty.

This was the first beer I tried on my first trip to Germany and after hundreds of beer taste tests, this is still #1 on my list.  You haven’t truly tasted an Erdinger until you’ve had it with a slice of orange in it. (exactly the way it’s served in it’s native country)

Bottle.  Orange-amber in colour with a thin white dissipating head, some lace.  The aroma was of bananas, yeast, oranges, slightly sweet, standard stuff.  The flavour was of light citrus (orange zest), some bananas, pepper and spices.  Creamy mouthfeel, light body, medium carbonation.  Finishes with a mild lingering bitterness.  Not to bad.

[bottle from LCBO]
Cloudy brownish orange with a fuzzy, white cover that clings to the glass.  Surprisingly hoppy aroma with lemony malt and some wheaty sourness.  Not the expected phenolics or esters characteristic of this style.  Pleasant citrusy malt flavour with a little cloviness coming out at the end as the flavour recedes to a clean finish.  Light to medium body with high carbonation.  This is really a nice session beer, but not really a weissbier.

Bottle.  Pours cloudy straw yellow with a fizzy frothy off-white head with lots of fast rising tiny bubbles.  Wheat and bananas to start with yeast (dough) and malt (cookie) aromas with lemon zest notes.  Mildly bitter creamy malt wheat flavor with lemon notes and faint bananas.  Medium to light bodied creamy yet fizzy palate with a somewhat dry finish.

This beer has all the attributes that a good German hefe-weizen should have -- banana, clove and yeasty-bready aroma, banana, clove, yeasty-bready and slight citrus flavor, pale cloudy yellowish amber hue, nice foamy long-lasting head, et cetera. What this beer has that sets it apart from its style contemporaries is a wonderfully sweet element in its flavor and aftertaste, as if there were residual candy sugar. The purist in me wants to knock off points for being out of character for the style, but I just can’t. The intriguing sweetness makes this perhaps the most enjoyable hefe-weizen to come out of Bavaria. So maybe I’m overrating this beer, but I make no apologies for that. I just love this stuff.

(500 ml bottle: $2.19 at Hi-Time Wine Cellars in Costa Mesa, CA) This German Hefeweizen smells pretty close to the oft-crappy American Wheat beers, kind of grassy, a little sweet, and when considering the style, quite lacking in the expected banana, clove and bubblegum aromas.  The flavor is also lacking the characteristics I’m looking for in a quality German Hefeweizen.  It’s kind of wheaty/grainy, lightly bitter and citrusy tart, and somewhat sweet, and so it tastes like a really flavorful American Wheat with only a touch of banana and yeast flavors.  Medium bodied, but not especially lively on the palate.  Pale golden color and fully cloudy in appearance.  Bubbly, white head does a great volcano imitation on the initial pour, but with all subsequent pours, it barely musters more than a sheen.  Eventually, there isn’t even a small ring, but the carbonation bubbles keep a-rising.  This isn’t a bad Hefeweizen, but there are certainly better out there.

Bottle. Golden orange color, hazy, with big white head. Not a lot in the nose: faint citrus, yeast, light wheat grain, banana sweetness, copper. Flavor is pretty light, mostly grain malt with some banana-like sweetness toward the end. On the verge of a light American pils, but saved by a somewhat hefty body, though this may be due only to high carbonation. Very drinkable, but not as interesting as I’d hoped.

on tap at the local bowling center.. it pours an off orange color w/ a thick white head that laces well.  Aroma was bubble gum, light fruits and some spices with hints of wheat.  The palate was pretty solid good mouth feel and decent coating.  The flavor had hints of bannanna and lots of wheat a light malt and a bit of something just off.  Overall I guess I could drink it again.

I just love it! Not the best for me but... I love it!! Spice, soft wheat and bubblegum aromas. Hazy apricot, fair sized, rocky white head. Flavour has wheat, banana and some corriander.As hefe weizens go, it’s an adequate sample, and goes down nice, and refreshing.

Sampled on tap, this beer pours to a dense white head and dense sheet-style lacing atop a straw colored body.  The aroma has a strong clean wheat that faded pretty quickly and could not be stirred up easily.  The flavor is wheaty but very boring.  Light banana.  Almost stale grains.  The palate actually has some character, however.  It was medium bodied and creamy.
Not my thing at all. Fizzy orange and aspartame and TCP and stale tinned bitter. From the tap - and not cheap.

From the bottle
Pours a cloudy wheat with a fluffy and long-lasting head.

The aroma is mostly hay with a spot of banana; the flavor yields those, with a hint of lemon sourness, a hint of chalk, and a bit of copper. The mouthfeel is a bit thin but pleasant enough. Drinkable, with no glaringly unpleasant features, but not a particularly impressive example of the style.

bottle. LCBO. cloudy light golden body with a huge frothy white head and sticky lace. aroma is dusty, heavy peppery spice, and sweet malt. rather clean tasting, lacking in fruity yeast and dimension. Spicy finish.
Draft at SDBC.  Typical Hefe.  Poured hazy orange.  Aromas of yeast and citrus.  Flavors similar.  Not much banana like in the super good hefe’s.  not too bad, just not super memorable.

A yellow orange cloudy colour with a significant fluffy head. A light sweet taste with a noticeable fresh bread aroma. Light body, thin texture and average carbonation. 
A refreshing beer for hot weather, perhaps with a sandwitch with mozzarella and tomatoes or a hot dog.
A yellow-orange colour with a big white fluffy head. The flavour is fruity and a bit sweet. A refreshing brew. (Bottle 50cl)
Big bottle.  Pours a fizzy cloudy orange.  Not much aroma, and missing the banana, clove, and spice of so many excellent hefeweizens.  A let down.

Lightly hazed pale sparkling golden colour with a bubbling white head.  Sweet malty nose with light hints of bubblegum and a nice candyish sugarcane type thing going on - light citrus notes.  The body is spritzy and light.  The middle has some sweet malt and a light yeastiness.  Tinge of tart at the back with a sweet malty end.  Not a very good hefeweizen - certainly don’t know why it’s one of the most popular in Germany.  Timid and spritzy.

Hazy yellow in color, fluffy white head.  Fantastic aroma filled with fresh bread and fruits.  Excellent wheat flavor with sweet yeast hints.  This was a great beer and reminded me why I love wheat beers!

Pours a cloudy pale yellow of a hue that almost glows. Respectable fluffy whilte head. Nice looking beer. Banana and cheese aromas with a hint of lime. Smooth yet lively texture. Again, a banana aspect is noticable in the flavor, and there’s something about the taste  and texture that reminds me of ice cream. Aroma and flavor is neither too string nor weak, a good balance. Overall, a pretty decent weiss.
Very enjoyable hefe, each hefe I drink I like more than the last.very "tangy" to the tongue.
Decidedly too much overhauled beer of frumento.  Torbid, it remembers a lot vaguely the kapuziner beer
Cloudy yello with a white head. Has a sweet tase. Banana in the aroma. Also some lemon.  Wheat in taste. Refreching.

Poured a cloudy gold, with a very minimal head despite the fizz. Can’t find any of the typical banana or cloves in the aroma, just some yeast and hops and maybe some lemon. Also can’t find much about this beer to get excited for, but then again it is not a bad beer. Flavour is tolerably sweet, with some bitterness. Palate is average. Yep, average all round (4 3 7 2 11 - 2.7).
Re-rate: Sampling this again, my notes are somewhat different, but the end rating is the same. Mostly got citrus and toffee in the aroma with some banana on tasting, some acidic burn and salt in the flavour, and a palate high in carbonation that is biting on the tongue but gives a pleasant toffee finish.
Lovely hazy gold, with a typical frothy white head. Nose is rather lightly spiced...again typical. Good..er..um typical wheat beer, can’t fault it, but unexceptional. Vic Wine.

Bottle.  Poured the nice cloudy yellow with a large white head.  Looked very nice in my Paulaner weiss glass.  The aroma was very faint of banana and spice.  Flavor was also lacking, too watery.  Too thin is a good way to put it.  Middle of the road German hefe, certainly not at the top of its class.

0.5l poured into an Erdinger Weiss glass. Hazy yellow, thick white head. Mild clovey aroma with a hint of yeastiness. Fizzy pale malts with a hint of of cloves and hops. Refreshing and light, though lacking a bit in the pehnol department.

A good middle-of-the-pack summer hefe. Looked great: cloudy lemon curd colour with a 1.5cm mat of foam that lasted and laced well. Plenty of bananas’n’cream in a sweetish aroma, plus green apples. Missing much hop presence. Fairly fizzy in the mouth - bit overcarbonated for my taste. Medium bodied and smooth. At the milder end of the hefe flavour scale but very clean-tasting. Sweet and fruity, with classic banana notes.
hazy gold, foamy white head.  aroma of apple, banana, yeast and wheat.  very thin moutfeel.  flavours are balanced but light.  lemony dry finish.

Bottle. Pale yellow in color with a nice white fluffy head. Malty hoppy aroma. Banana and clove notes. Spicey. Malty and hoppy flavor.  Light and refreshing.  Well balanced.  Crisp. Drinkable. Enjoyable.

Good but too thin. It has a nice yeast and sweet malt aroma. The appearance is hazy but not full of particulates. The flavor is a nice balance of malt and hops. It has the fruity taste that is so vital to good Hefe-Weizen beer. The palate on the other hand is thin. Aftertaste is sweet but fades quickly leaving the impression that this is a dry style. Overall a good beer but there are better wheat beers out there.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy yellow with a large fizzy white head, nice carbonation -- looks really good for a wheat beer. Best part of the aroma: no banana! In my wheat beer experience that’s quite rare. Aroma does have a light wheaty malt smell. The flavour of wheat,  malt and grain is pleasant but mild, it needs more oomph! A nice summer patio beer.

Bottle.  Looks fantastic - a dark yellow with a huge fluffy white head and tons of active bubbles - lovely.  Very light yeasty aroma.  Light taste as well - bland and watery with only hints of malt and maybe some spice but I’m stretching.  Too bad, I loved how this looked, but I won’t be buying this again.
pours golden with a small head.Aromas of apples.Taste was of apples on a wheat ceral.Was medium bodied with a smoooth apply finish.
Draft. Pale yellow & cloudy.  Lemony smell.  Hints of fruit (bananas?) in the flavour. No aftertaste. Bit watery.

Bottle (500ml) - little drunk this afternoon, last balcony tasting of the day.  Pours lemony yellow, cloudy - plenty of bubbly white head.  Aroma of lemon furniture polish, sour corn mash, malt, and cedar - corny grain.  Interesting lacing.  Flavour is fairly bland, orange and wheat and malt and grainy bitterness to finish.  Not bad, not great.

Bottle - July 2005

Pours a medium golden color, cloudy but not very cloudy for a hefe.Head is abundant, white and wide (leaves somewhat a lacing). Aroma is very slightly yeasty and very neutral overall. Taste is the same, lacking the sting, citrus and tartness one would expect from a wheat. Aftertaste is almost non existant or very neutral. Overall a pretty unimpresive brew, which further disappointed me because it is one of the fews that i have the brand´s glassware to taste from, furthermore, i would say the glass itself is far more usefull than the beer!!
Not bad but completely forgetable.

A medium yellow color, cloudy but not very cloudy for a hefe.  Medium full head.  Light wheat malt aroma.  Subtle wheat malt and bananas interplay with a wee bit of bitter hops.  Very sweet without the balancing yeasty, sharp, peppery bite I prefer in a perfect hefe.  Merely average.

Pours a hazy yellow color with a thick creamy white head. Aroma of wheat with very weak bananas. Flavor of wheat and bananas. Light to medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation. It’s very average.

(bottle) Cloudy yellow colour with a large white foam. Not much aroma but some yeasty and citric elements. Taste of wheat bread but very average, short and slightly fruity finish. Drinkable but boring.

Dry, lagerish aroma with faint wheat. Only becomes more odorous when the yeast is poured in from the bottom of the glass, making it smell like doughy wheat. Color is initially hazy gold, but becomes a little darker when the yeast is poured in. Very large pillowy white head. Served in a Carlsberg pilsner glass which likely accentuated the head on the pour. Tons of bubbles rushing to the top of the glass, reminiscent of champagne. Flavor is disappointing. Smooth and somewhat doughy, but doesn’t exert itself enough. Despite all the visible carbonation, the mouthfeel is only softly carbonated. Just really too blah to be memorable. However, this is probably a good transitional beer for somebody whose never had weissbiers, and although flavorwise this brew tastes almost as much like a lager than a weissbier, it is significantly better than the average pale lager. A thought just came to mind. Will brewers like Erdinger Weissbrau read our reviews and discover that their weissbier is only average and therefore tweak the recipe? If so, over the next 5-10 years we really could see a quality surge in beer.

Hazy blonde with a thick creamy white head which persists. Light wheaty malt aroma with none of the banana/cloves notes associated with weizen. In mouth, this is more of a malty fruity taste with faint bananas. Decent medium bodied. The weakest of the LCBO weizen release (summer 2005).

Though this beer seems catered to an American audience, there remain enough classic elements to give it something approaching a recommendation. This beer has wheat cloudiness but instead of the typical tan-yellow it has a decidedly golden tint (opaque nonetheless). Aroma is SADly like a cheap corn-based malt liquor/pale lager -- how did this come about?! Luckily the flavor has more to speak of, with lots of yeast and a good malt backdrop; still, the pale lager comparison sticks somewhat. But overall not a bad choice at $2.50 per bottle. What can I say, it beats most ... American inner-city malt liquors ... by a mile.

Bottle: Very cloudy gold with a large white head. Looks good! Golden malt aromas with restrained wheat and background floral notes with a touch of fennel. Sweet honey-like wheat flavours with some faint spicyness and citrussy hop notes and echos of banana. Nice, easy, and refreshing, though without any of the complexity and presence of the greater Hefe’s. Nice work nonetheless.

A Mes rate:
I’m only drinking this as it was all i could get that was decent. Poor show huh? Standard white. Nose is slighty mouldy and not particularly pleasing. Flavour is pretty much more of the same. In fact there is not much flavour at all. Leaves a thick feeling in the mouth. Erm... there are MUCH better whites than this...

Bottle at Westgate Wetherspoons Canterbury.  The flavours are not as strong as other wheat beers, but it looks the part with a cloudy golden colour and a thick white head.  Slight citrus, a bit of banana and a bit of yeasty spiciness, but otherwise very refreshing

bottled.  Pours earthy brown, dark and hazy with a foamy tan head.  The smell suggests sweet hops and malt.  Oddly enough, in the taste I find some almonds, with other sweet and familiar but elusive flavors.

Tasted in Toronto.  Obtained from LCBO as part of the summer series.  Tasted in dimple mug.  Appearance is straw colour yellow, cloudy with sustained white head. Aroma is of slight yeast, banana, candy floss, but very very faint.  Flavour is more subdued, with a hint of clove, but fairly muted and subtle.
Bottle. A classic German wheatbeer. Aroma is very banana. Flavor is quite elegant; slightly herby, sweet and banana.

I’ve been waiting quite a while for this beer to appear in bottles at the L.C.B.O.. I was speaking to a beer rep about Erdinger. He described it as being the most popular Weissbier in the world, leading me to believe it was the Budweiser of Hefe-Weizen. Although not all that bad it did not disappoint. Pale hazy gold with a short wite head. Barnyard and cheap sweet hot dog rolls in the aroma. Honey and grass. Slightly cheese with some mineral salts. Boring with very little character. Had this with seven other Weissbiers. This was the dud.

500ml brown bottle. Poured a lemony-gold colour. Head starts large and foamy, settles to a small half inch white cap. Slight haze. Bananas dominate aroma, with light clove (?).
